Title: the dependence transcendence

Scene: In the university, Sheldon is asleep against a vending machine.
Howard: It’s pretty late. You think I’ve got time to run some more simulations on the cooling system?
What?
Hey, hey, hey, you’re not going anywhere.
Well, wake up, we’re gonna put in a lot of late nights.
Well, I don’t know, midnight, one.
If you’re tired, have some coffee.
I am having coffee.
Sorry I have to work all weekend.
Thanks again for breakfast.
Why is it taking him so long to get a drink out of a vending machine?
You wanted him awake.
Maybe we should break for lunch. What time is it?
Why don’t you just go home?
You can’t develop a problem that fast.
Well, this probably won’t work, but has anyone ever tried to just haul off and whup the crazy out of him?
No worries.
That was painful to watch.
No.
When the baby gets here, you gotta teach me that.
We’ve hit a bit of a snag. We’re already behind schedule.
We, we’re thinking, two years.
That’s it? You’re okay with that?
Yes, thank you so much.
Leonard: Sure, I’m still figuring out the thermo-acoustic expander.
We only have two months to deliver this to the Air Force because of you.
Guys, we’re not gonna get anything done if we start fighting. Now, can you please try
It’s been three and a half minutes, wake up.
Oh, I had a good dream that when I carried you to bed, I let your head hit the wall and I laughed.
What is this?
Oh, that is so nice.
So, what are you guys gonna do today?
You don’t think you’ll be bored?
Oh, it’s complicated. He finds pushing that little door and reaching up into the machine
Are you okay?
According to the world’s worst cuckoo clock, it’s two.
What?
So?
You only had one.
We can’t afford to lose any more time.
That’s not helpful. It’s fun to think about, but it’s not helpful. Hey, Sheldon, we are on a serious time crunch. We can’t do this without you. Can you please pull it together?
Thank you.
I’m gonna get some coffee. You want some?
Uh, okay, let’s pretend you do have a problem.
You don’t.
No, you don’t. But let’s say you do. And don’t say you do, because you don’t. Now, wouldn’t you think that throwing yourself into your work would be the best way to deal with it?
Your problem.
Is it about the rotational symmetries you should be figuring out or your fake caffeine problem?

Sheldon. We are dealing with an impossible deadline from the Air Force because of you. So have an energy drink, don’t have an energy drink. Order suppositories and shove ’em wherever you want, I don’t care.
Right. Listen to me. We can’t do anything until you do your part. So get up in front of this whiteboard and do it.
Yes, you can.
Seriously?
It’s okay, we’ll figure something out.
It’ll be fine. You’ll see. Sheldon? Buddy? (Sheldon snores)
Um, I don’t really know how to say this.
Right. Sorry, sir.
Sir.
I understand that we’re under contract, and I don’t know what the consequences of violating that are, but, uh, we’re not gonna be able to deliver in the time we promised.
Thanks for understanding, sir.
Sheldon: Oh, while you do that I am going to pump cerebral spinal fluid through my brain cells to remove the metabolic by-products of the day’s thoughts.
It’s called sleep and it’s my bedtime. Nighty-night, y’all.
I know, I was there.
How late?
One o’clock? I’m not a raccoon.
What? You have some coffee.
And look how irritable it’s making you!
Fine. (Time passing montage) I don’t think I can go much longer.
I had a bad dream that my best friend became a tyrant and forced me to stay up all night to work.
Ow, it does hurt.
Oh, that was never happening.
I won’t be there.
Huh, what?
Oh, no, thank you, those have caffeine in them.
I am cool. This is Yoo-hoo, chocolate milk’s delicious watery cousin.
Superheroes take performance-enhancing chemicals?
I am facing a great deal of work. And I do like things better when famous people also like them.
The first one’s free? Flash, how do you stay in business?

Gentlemen, I am ready to work. To quote The Martian, let’s science the faeces out of this. That’s The Martian the book and The Martian the movie, not Marvin the Martian. Although to quote Marvin the Martian, I claim this planet in the name of Mars.
Oh, I’m fantastic, never been better. I had my first energy drink and I feel great. Hey, you guys want to wrestle? We can do arm, thumb, mud, sumo. Nah, we’re not fat enough, or wearing diapers.
My head hurts and I’m more tired than ever.
No, I can do this. I just, I just need another energy drink. Oh, no.
I want another one.
That’s a craving. That’s a sign of chemical dependency.
No, I know, but plenty of things are addictive after a single exposure. I mean, crack cocaine, nicotine, Pringles. You know once one pops one just can’t stop.
You want to bet? Oh, great, now I’m addicted to gambling.
I’m sorry. Yes, of course.
Just, please, bear with me if I display symptoms of caffeine withdrawal.
You guys stink.
Uh, you’re really going to have caffeine in front of me when I’m trying to get my life back on track?
I do.
Yeah, but I do.
With what?
I thought I didn’t have a problem.
Leonard, can I ask you a question?
Howard, can I ask you a question?

All right, I’ll just toss this out to the room. Um, I was thinking that the best way to fight my addiction is by weaning myself off in steps. Now, I couldn’t find a caffeine patch, but I did find what claims to be a mind-boosting caffeine suppository. You know, the interesting fact about the rectum…
You don’t shove them. They come with an easy-glide applicator.
I can’t.
No, I can’t figure out the math. I’ve been racking my brain for days, and I’ve got nothing.
I can’t do it. I’m not as smart as I think I am. I’m so sorry. This is all my fault.
But what if we can’t?
He said start with it, not end with it.
The computations required to overcome the deployability issues are more significant than we thought.
We, we really appreciate it.
Penny: Good morning.
Oh, I’ll go. I like a party.
It’s okay, I’ll still go.
Oh, I’ll have some wine and listen to people go on about crap I don’t understand. I mean, how is it any different than every single day of my life?
Hi.
How early are we?
I suddenly wish Sheldon was here.
So should we talk to each other or mingle?
Yeah, I mean, I could see him eating one or two guests, but not a whole party.
Oh, it’s funny, I was just thinking the same thing about you.
Wait, what do you mean she’s her?
No.
What? You tell me about your foot fungus, but this is a secret?
Now Sheldon’s popular? What is happening?
You trend setter.
Okay, okay, so Amy’s cool, Sheldon’s cool. Tell me about Leonard.
Leonard Hofstadter.
That’s me, I’m her. You know, he didn’t trick me, he just wore me down.
You know, I had no idea Caltech is exactly like my high school.
Wow, you popular girls are mean.
Well, so are you. In fact, you know what? We will never take you for granite. Did you get that? Granite? A little geology joke.
Okay.
Amy: Well, we didn’t see you last night, we’re not gonna see you today, so we thought we could have breakfast together.
Well, Sheldon was supposed to go to this party with me this afternoon, but I don’t think that’s happening.

Well, to be honest, it’s not like a party party, it’s more like a gathering where scientists of different disciplines get together to share their work and keep current on what’s going on in other fields. I don’t know why I called it a party, sorry.
Hi, Bert. This is my friend, Penny.
Oh, actually, we’re an hour late.
I don’t know where everyone is.
Okay. I feel so bad about leaving him here.
I’m sure it’s just ’cause I’m dating Sheldon.
Just the right idea at the right time.
And you thought this wasn’t gonna be a great party.
Well, it’s not exactly like it. We’re all extremely smart.
Thank you so much, Bert. This was great.
Leonard:: Look at that, it is a party.
Bernadette: It’s okay.
You shouldn’t have made the alarm code his birthday.
Oh, I appreciate it, but you don’t have to spend your day off with me.
Not really.
I get enough of that when I take Howard to my grandmother’s for Christmas.
Isn’t it a little early for that?
Oh, there’s so much junk in there, it’s embarrassing.
I don’t think you are.
I don’t even know where to begin.
Oh, I was gonna start at the end. Thank God you’re here.
Sorry. I should probably keep this in case we have a girl.
My dad built it for me.
This was the husband and this was the wife. They’d go out on adventures together. Cruises, skiing, horseback riding. That was really me just duct taping them to our dog.
They did, but the mommy and daddy didn’t like them, so they shipped them off to an orphanage I made out of a shoebox.

Not every girl dreams about being a mom. Sometimes you think you’re never gonna have kids and one day you wake up and you’re pregnant. And it doesn’t matter that your career’s going great right now and that you and your husband never even got to go anywhere taped to a dog.
Sorry I flipped out on you. I think it’s just hormones.
Does it really need one?
Well, it doubled as my dad’s office, and he was a cop, so I guess the theme was bloody homicide photos.
Are you just gonna name all the colours?
I don’t care what colour the room is.
Well, you’re not, so just drop it. (Off) I’m clearly upset. Why aren’t you following me?
I don’t know.
Raj, why don’t I care about anything?
It’s my baby. I, I should care about nurseries and colours, and I don’t. What’s wrong with me?
I keep waiting to feel excited, but it’s not happening. What if it never happens?
Once, I was supposed to babysit my brothers. Our neighbour found them naked in the backyard eating crickets.
What? Why? Who are you calling? You’re gonna rat me out to Howard, aren’t you? You’re such a snitch, no wonder I don’t like you.
Something’s wrong. I don’t care about any of the baby stuff every other mom is so into. Honestly, I’m not even sure I like babies.
But I thought I’d be more excited.
Thank you. I feel better now.
Raj: Well, I didn’t get to see you last night. It was the least I could do.
So, what should we do today?
Well, I don’t mind. Oh, you want go to the mall and look at baby stuff?
Oh, come on, we could share a pretzel and get sideways glances from racist old ladies.
Oh, I know, why don’t we get started on clearing out the baby’s room?
You have to get to it eventually.
How can you be embarrassed around me? I’m gonna be in the room with you when you give birth.
You didn’t think I was gonna be in your kitchen this morning, yet here I am.
Well, in The Sound of Music, Julie Andrews says let’s start at the very beginning, a very good place to start.
Well, I think the first thing we should get rid of is that tone.
Oh, that’s a nice one. Was it yours when you were little?
Wow, it’s so cute.
Oh, and did they have kids?
Yeah, that’s not worrisome at all.
I skipped spin class for this.
I think you were mean before you were pregnant, but it’s fine. So, uh, instead of cleaning out the room, why don’t we just decide on a theme for the nursery?
Of course it does. Didn’t your baby room have a theme?
Oh. Mine was Winnie the Pooh. But anyway, why don’t we just take a step back and start with a colour? Right? There are so many amazing ones. Red, blue, green, purple.
Well, not now.
Okay, well, I’m just trying to help you.
Sorry. Sorry.
So where are we going?
Okay. How Thelma and Louise of us.
I’m sorry?
Well, crime-scene photos near your crib spring to mind.
Bernadette, come on, look, you’re overthinking this, okay? You’re gonna be an amazing mom. Even if you don’t believe it, I know you have maternal instincts.
Happy and well-fed. You see, that’s what I’m taking from that story.
Uh, pull over.
Whoa, I’m calling my dad, okay? He’s got experience dealing with pregnant ladies because he’s an OBGYN. And experience with crazy ladies because of my mom.
What? No.
No.

Well I don’t.

Okay, well, thanks for coming by. You’re nice people.
